bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 17, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes that he has been delayed in Boykins on his way back to New York.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, May 17, 1875
div1.p:
It is stranger than
fiction, but nevertheless it is most
true. Here am I at Boykins and, what
is of far greater import, I am likely
to remain all the day. There was an ex-
cursion train, to-day, instead of the reg-
ular accommodation train, & that jolly
train passed here at 9.38 A.M.; thus leaving
me in all my glory & alone- Ah! that
is the sad part of it- If you were only
here, I could stay forever. I have
a great notion to return to M. & remain
till, to-morrow; but no! 'twould only end
in another farewell & Heaven knows
it grieves me to say goodbye to you.

I have half an idea to go straight
on to my sister's, as I have twice dis-
appointed my brother. I could return
& spend the early part of June
with him.

Would write more, but Mr
Myrick's boy can't wait any longer.
Excuse the paper, but so anxious
was I to send you a greeting, that
I should have written on a
dry leaf rather than have missed
the opportunity.
